unit_name: Unit 11 - Pressure regulators, overpressure protection, meters, and fuel containers

8th_2025.unit_name: Unit 11 - Pressure regulators, overpressure protection, meters, and fuel containers

topics: Droop (outlet pressure lower than setpoint during flow)
chapters.content:
Pressure regulators are essential components in gas distribution systems, maintaining constant gas pressure at appliance inlets regardless of upstream pressure variations or downstream demand changes.

Regulator Components:

Three key elements in a pressure regulator:

1. Restricting element (valve disc): Controls gas flow through the regulator
2. Measuring element (diaphragm): Senses downstream pressure
3. Loading element (spring): Provides the force to set desired outlet pressure

Forces in a Regulator:

Opening force: Created by the adjustable spring above the diaphragm, pushing down to open the valve
Closing force: Created by the pressure under the diaphragm (downstream pressure), pushing up to close the valve

Regulator Equilibrium:

A regulator is in equilibrium when the opening force of the spring equals the closing force of the downstream pressure. At this point, the valve disc maintains a position that delivers the exact pressure setpoint.

Adjusting Downstream Pressure:

To increase downstream pressure: Screw down the adjusting screw (compresses spring, increases opening force)
To decrease downstream pressure: Screw out the adjusting screw (releases spring tension, decreases opening force)

Atmospheric Vent:

The atmospheric vent allows air above the diaphragm to escape or enter as the diaphragm moves. This ensures the diaphragm can respond accurately to downstream pressure changes. A blocked vent port can cause incorrect regulator operation.

Installing Backward:

If a regulator is installed backward, the regulator will open completely because the high inlet pressure acts on the wrong side of the diaphragm, forcing it fully open.

Pressure Characteristics:

Droop: The condition when outlet pressure is lower than the setpoint pressure during flow conditions. As flow increases through a regulator, downstream pressure decreases.

Lockup Pressure: The pressure downstream of a regulator under no flow conditions (static conditions). This is typically slightly higher than the flowing setpoint.

Pitot Tube:

A pitot tube in a regulator increases upstream pressure sensing during flow conditions, keeping downstream pressure closer to the setpoint during flow. It provides more accurate pressure control under varying flow rates.

Regulator Categories:

Service regulator: Reduces service line pressure to building line pressure at the gas meter set
Appliance regulator: Reduces building line pressure to appliance manifold pressure
First-stage regulator: Used in propane systems to reduce container pressure to intermediate pressure
Line pressure regulator: Maintains building line pressure (typically 2 psig or 5 psig systems)

Special Regulator Types:

Zero governor: Designed to deliver gas at zero gauge pressure in proportion to the suction pressure created by mechanical air flow to a premix burner

Air/gas proportioning regulator: Delivers gas under pressure in proportion to the pressure created by mechanical air flow to a nozzle mix burner (not zero pressure like zero governor)

Two-stage regulators: Required in all permanent propane installations. First stage reduces container pressure to intermediate pressure (typically 10 psig), second stage reduces to appliance pressure (7 in w.c. or 11 in w.c.)

Automatic changeover regulator: Allows continuous gas flow when changing propane cylinders. Gas flow is NOT interrupted when changing a cylinder because the regulator automatically switches to the reserve cylinder.

Vent Requirements:

Per CSA B149.1 Clause 5.2.1.7, regulators operating above 2 psig require properly sized vent piping. For a 5 psig line pressure regulator with a 3/4 in vent tapping running 65 ft, use 1 in pipe for the entire length and make the change at the vent tapping.

Exception: A pressure regulator operating at 2 psig or less is exempt from vent piping requirements when equipped with a vent leak-limiting system.

Undersized vent pipe may cause the regulator to respond slowly or sluggishly.

Reference Tube:

The purpose of a reference tube connected to combination gas valve regulator vent is to enable the regulator to automatically adjust for pressure changes in the burner enclosure (used in induced draft systems).

Hydrostatic Relief Valve:

Used in liquid propane systems to relieve pressure buildup from thermal expansion of trapped liquid propane.

Maximum Propane Pressure:

The maximum allowed propane pressure in a single-family dwelling is 5 psig (except for specific appliances rated for 10 psig).

Flow Rate Expression:

Flow rate for a regulator is usually expressed in scf/h (standard cubic feet per hour).

Regulator Sizing:

When selecting a line pressure regulator for a 2 psig natural gas system sized for maximum allowable pressure drop, use the minimum operating inlet pressure (0.5 PSI) for capacity table selection to ensure adequate capacity under worst-case conditions.

The arrow on a regulator body should point downstream (in the direction of gas flow), not upstream.

Propane Vapor Inlet Pressure:

When sizing a propane regulator system, the cylinder outside temperature determines the lowest expected vapor inlet pressure. As temperature drops, propane vapor pressure decreases, reducing available inlet pressure to the regulator.

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following is the restricting element of a regulator?
Which of the following is the measuring element of a regulator?
Which of the following is the loading element of a regulator?
Which of the following would cause an appliance regulator to have too low an outlet pressure?
What is the purpose of a gas pressure regulator?
options: a) To keep the colour of the flame constant
b) To maintain an even outlet heated air temperature
c) To maintain a constant gas pressure at the gas valve inlet
d) To increase and maintain higher pressures as the load increases
assignment_questions.correct_answer: c) To maintain a constant gas pressure at the gas valve inlet

assignment_questions.question: In a gas pressure regulator, what creates the closing force?
options: b) The inlet pressure to the regulator
c) The pressure under the diaphragm
d) The adjustable spring above the diaphragm
assignment_questions.correct_answer: c) The pressure under the diaphragm

assignment_questions.question: In a gas pressure regulator, what creates the opening force?
options: b) The inlet pressure to the regulator
c) The pressure under the diaphragm
d) The adjustable spring above the diaphragm
assignment_questions.correct_answer: d) The adjustable spring above the diaphragm

assignment_questions.question: How do you increase the downstream pressure of a regulator?
options: b) Screw out the adjusting screw
c) Screw down the adjusting screw
d) Replace the restricting disc and the spring
assignment_questions.correct_answer: c) Screw down the adjusting screw

assignment_questions.question: In a regulator, what is the purpose of the atmospheric vent?
options: a) It allows gas to escape
c) It allows air above the diaphragm to escape or enter
d) It allows a connection for a secondary pilot
assignment_questions.correct_answer: c) It allows air above the diaphragm to escape or enter

assignment_questions.question: A pressure regulator is in equilibrium when _______.
options: a) The opening force of the diaphragm is equal to the closing force of the orifice
b) The opening force of the diaphragm is equal to the closing force of the spring
c) The opening force of the spring is equal to the closing force of the upstream pressure
d) The opening force of the spring is equal to the closing force of the downstream pressure
assignment_questions.correct_answer: d) The opening force of the spring is equal to the closing force of the downstream pressure

assignment_questions.question: _______ is the condition when the outlet pressure is lower than the setpoint pressure during flow conditions.
If a regulator is installed backward in a piping system, what is the most likely result?
options: a) The regulator will open completely
b) The regulator will close completely
c) The pressure downstream will rise above the setpoint
d) No difference; the valves are non-directional
assignment_questions.correct_answer: a) The regulator will open completely

assignment_questions.question: What is the purpose of a pitot tube in a regulator?
options: a) To provide mechanical advantage for positive shutoff
b) To relieve unwanted gases when overpressure occurs
c) To increase upstream pressure during static conditions
d) To keep downstream pressure closer to the setpoint during flow conditions
assignment_questions.correct_answer: d) To keep downstream pressure closer to the setpoint during flow conditions

assignment_questions.question: When the flow rate increases through a regulator, what happens to the downstream pressure?
A 5 psig line pressure regulator has a 3/4 in vent tapping and the vent line must run 65 ft. What must be done?
options: a) Use a 3/4 in pipe for the first 20 ft, then increase to 1 in
b) Use a 3/4 in pipe for the first 50 ft, then increase to 1 in
c) Use a 3/4 in pipe for the entire length
d) Use a 1 in pipe for the entire length and make the change at the vent tapping
assignment_questions.correct_answer: d) Use a 1 in pipe for the entire length and make the change at the vent tapping

assignment_questions.question: A pressure regulator operating at 2 psig or less shall be exempt from vent requirements when equipped with _______.
options: b) An internal relief valve spring
c) A union on the downstream piping
d) A pitot tube and balancing diaphragm

assignment_questions.question: The _______ category of gas pressure regulators are used to reduce the service line pressure to building line pressure at the gas meter set.
An undersized vent pipe on a regulator may cause the _______.
options: b) Restriction of an element to stay fully open
c) Restriction of an element to stay fully closed
d) Regulator responding slowly or sluggishly
assignment_questions.correct_answer: d) Regulator responding slowly or sluggishly

assignment_questions.question: The purpose of a reference tube connected to the combination gas valve regulator vent is _______.
options: a) To supply the pilot gas flow
b) To activate the combustion fan pressure switch
c) To vent the upper diaphragm chamber into the combustion chamber
d) To enable the regulator to automatically adjust for pressure changes in the burner enclosure
assignment_questions.correct_answer: d) To enable the regulator to automatically adjust for pressure changes in the burner enclosure

assignment_questions.question: Lockup pressure is _______.
options: a) The pressure downstream of a regulator under no flow conditions
b) The pressure downstream of a regulator under full flow conditions
c) The pressure downstream of a regulator during full relief conditions
d) The pressure downstream of a regulator that activates the internal relief valve
assignment_questions.correct_answer: a) The pressure downstream of a regulator under no flow conditions

assignment_questions.question: A hydrostatic relief valve is used in _______.
options: d) Natural gas service meter sets

assignment_questions.question: The maximum allowed propane pressure in a single-family dwelling is _______.
A zero governor is designed to deliver gas at zero gauge pressure in proportion to the suction pressure created by mechanical air flow to a premix burner.
A _______ regulator arrangement is required in all permanent propane installations.
If an automatic changeover regulator is used on an installation, gas flow will be interrupted by changing a propane cylinder.
An air/gas proportioning regulator delivers gas under pressure in proportion to the pressure created by mechanical air flow to a nozzle mix burner.
Which of the following is usually used to express the rate of flow for a regulator?

You are selecting the line pressure regulator for a 2 psig natural gas system that has had the pipe sized for the maximum allowable pressure drop. Which operating inlet pressure would you use for the regulator capacity tables?
The arrow on a regulator body should point upstream.
When sizing a propane regulator system, which of the following determines the lowest expected vapor inlet pressure?

chapters.content:
Overpressure protection devices prevent downstream pressure from exceeding the maximum safe operating pressure of system components. Several methods provide overpressure protection in gas systems.

Maximum Allowable Pressure:

The maximum allowable pressure downstream of a pressure-controlling device is the lowest maximum pressure rating of any downstream component. All components must be protected to their lowest rated pressure.

Overpressure Protection Methods:

1. Pressure relief (venting excess gas)
2. Pressure limiting (containment with regulator systems)
3. Automatic shut-off (complete gas shut-off)

Direct-Operated Relief Valves:

Direct-operated relief valves measure system pressure with a diaphragm. The diaphragm senses downstream pressure and opens the relief valve when pressure exceeds the setpoint. A loading spring sets the relief pressure threshold.

Components:
- Loading spring (sets relief pressure)
- Diaphragm (measures system pressure)
- Valve disk (restricting element)
- Seat ring

Operation: When system pressure overcomes spring force, the diaphragm lifts, opening the valve to vent excess pressure to atmosphere.

Pitot Tube Relief Valves:

Pitot tube-operated relief valves decrease pressure buildup over setpoint during high flow conditions. When the valve opens, high fluid velocity through the seat ring creates low pressure near the pitot tube end. This draws fluid from above the diaphragm, helping open the valve. Result: increased relief capacity with reduced pressure buildup.

Adjusting Setpoint:

Remove the cap and turn the adjusting nut:
- Clockwise: Increases relief pressure
- Counterclockwise: Decreases relief pressure

Application: Direct-operated relief valves are commonly used in natural gas systems supplying commercial enterprises such as restaurants, laundries, and industrial furnaces.

Internal Relief Valves:

Regulators with internal relief valves may eliminate the requirement for external overpressure protection. The internal relief valve shares the main measuring diaphragm and is located in the center of it.

Components:
- Light-loading spring (for relief valve)
- Main measuring diaphragm (shared)
- Relief valve seat in center of main diaphragm
- Pusher post

Operation: During normal operation, both internal relief valve and main valve disc are closed. If overpressure develops (from dirt lodging or component failure), downstream pressure lifts the main diaphragm until the relief valve seat contacts the pusher post. Further pressure increase compresses both springs, separating the diaphragm and relief seat to vent gas through the center opening.

Note: The loading force of the relief valve spring is NOT adjustable. This design generally requires significant pressure buildup to reach maximum relief flow rate.

Application: Internal relief valves are used in service regulators, line pressure regulators, and appliance regulators for industrial equipment.

Sizing Relief Valves:

Relief valve size depends on:
- System type
- Pressure ranges
- Application requirements
- Manufacturer tables

Consult manufacturer tables before choosing a relief valve. Set the relief valve pressure higher than the regulator setpoint, but within downstream pressure limitations.

Venting Relief Valves:

Per CSA B149.1 Clause 5.5 and manufacturer specifications:

Minimum requirement: Relief valve vent must be at least the size of the vent outlet on the relief valve if termination point is less than 50 ft (15 m) away.

For additional length: For every additional 50 ft (15 m) or part thereof, increase vent outlet one size for its full length starting at the vent outlet.

Equivalent length: A 90° elbow = 3 ft (1 m)

For long lengths, contact manufacturer or AHJ.

Pressure-Limiting Regulator Systems:

Pressure limiting is overpressure control by containment. Pressure-limiting regulators are acceptable overpressure protection devices.

Three types:
1. Wide-open monitor
2. Series regulation
3. Working monitor

Wide-Open Monitor:

Two regulators piped in series, both sensing downstream pressure after the second regulator.

Components:
- Monitor regulator (setpoint slightly higher)
- Worker regulator (setpoint slightly lower)

Operation: Under normal conditions, monitor regulator is wide open. It only starts regulating if worker regulator fails.

Configurations:
- Upstream monitor: Monitor regulator ahead of worker
- Downstream monitor: Monitor regulator after worker

Disadvantage: Monitor rarely exercised, may become bound, sluggish, or damaged.

Series Regulation (Two-Cut Systems):

Two regulators in series, each taking a pressure "cut." The first unit maintains inlet pressure to the second valve within the maximum allowable operating pressure of the downstream system.

Advantage: If either regulator fails, the other maintains safe pressure downstream.

Working Monitors:

Combines elements of series regulation and wide-open monitors. Both regulators work continuously as series regulators taking two pressure cuts.

Operation:
- Worker pilot controls intermediate pressure at intermediate value
- Monitor pilot senses downstream pressure with setpoint slightly higher than required
- When both work correctly, monitor is fully open trying to raise system pressure
- Monitor allows worker pilot to control intermediate pressure
- Both regulators respond to demand changes

Advantage: Both regulators continuously working, preventing clogging or sticking.

Automatic Shut-Off (OPSO/Slam-Shut):

Accomplishes overpressure protection by complete containment - gas is shut off completely until malfunction is determined and device manually reset.

Application: Gas distribution companies use for places of public assembly (schools, hospitals, churches, shopping centers) as secondary overpressure protection. Also common in boiler combustion systems.

Token Relief:

The regulator typically has a token internal relief to avoid nuisance trips of slam-shut mechanism due to small pressure increase from minor orifice damage or small obstruction.

Operation: In overpressure conditions, safety plug is forced onto slam-shut seat, providing complete shutoff of gas flow. Some models also slam-shut on underpressure conditions (UPCO - Under Pressure Cut-Off).

Important: OPSO will NOT reset automatically - requires manual reset.

Effect of Blocked Vent:

If a regulator vent becomes blocked while the regulator is in the open position, the regulator would remain open because air above the diaphragm cannot escape, preventing the diaphragm from moving to close the valve.

Least Obvious Failure Warning:

Of commonly used overpressure protection methods, pressure limiting gives the least obvious failure warning because there is no venting or shutoff - one regulator fails and the other takes over silently.

Relief Valve Effect on Capacity:

A relief valve will NOT decrease the capacity of a regulator. Relief valves only activate during overpressure conditions and do not restrict normal gas flow.

Wide-Open Monitoring:

In wide-open monitoring systems, the monitor regulator is rarely exercised, which is a disadvantage because it may become bound or fail.

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following is the maximum allowable pressure downstream of a pressure-controlling device?
options: c) The lowest maximum pressure rating of any downstream components
d) The highest maximum pressure rating of any downstream components
assignment_questions.correct_answer: c) The lowest maximum pressure rating of any downstream components

assignment_questions.question: Of the commonly used overpressure protection methods, which gives the least obvious failure warning?
A relief valve will decrease the capacity of a regulator.
When using a direct-operated relief valve, system pressure is measured by a _______.
Which of the following types of overpressure protection incorporate a restricting element?
An OPSO will reset automatically.
What would happen if a regulator vent became blocked while the regulator was in the open position?
options: b) The regulator would remain open
c) The regulator would operate normally
d) The regulator setpoint would slowly drop
assignment_questions.correct_answer: b) The regulator would remain open

assignment_questions.question: Which type of pressure-limiting system has a regulator that is rarely exercised?

chapters.content:
Gas meters measure the volume of gas flowing through them. Understanding meter types, reading methods, and calculation procedures is essential for verifying appliance inputs and system operation.

Dial-Type Meters:

Most common type for residential installations. Two types of dials:

Consumption dial: Indicates amount of gas consumed, provides information for billing purposes

Test dial: Used to determine appliance input and detect downstream leaks. Shows immediate gas flow.

Each meter displays "PER REV" showing volume measured per revolution (e.g., 1/2 ft³, 2 ft³, 5 ft³, or 0.05 m³, 0.5 m³).

Clocking a Meter:

"Clocking" determines appliance input by timing test dial revolutions.

Procedure:
1. Ensure appliance being clocked is the ONLY appliance operating
2. Allow appliance to fire continuously for about 5 minutes
3. Take readings during stable operation
4. Record time for one complete revolution of test dial
5. Clock 2-3 times and use average
6. Check meter's units of measurement
7. Calculate volume per hour
8. Convert to Btu/h (multiply by 1000 Btu/ft³ for natural gas or 2500 Btu/ft³ for propane)
9. Compare to rated input on appliance rating plate

Important: Measured input should not exceed rated input or be less than 90% of rated input.

Formulas:

Imperial: (3600 sec/hour ÷ seconds per revolution) × test dial size (ft³) × Btu/ft³ = Btu/h input

Metric: (3600 sec/hour ÷ seconds per revolution) × test dial size (m³) × kW/m³ = kW input

Imperial and Metric Conversions:

Gas flow: 35.31 ft³ = 1 m³
Burner input: 3412 Btu/h = 1 kW
Natural gas CV: 1000 Btu/ft³ or 10.35 kW/m³

Flow Rates with Pressure Compensation:

When gas pressure exceeds 0.5 psig (3.5 kPa), flow rates require correction for pressure.

Formula: Q = [3600 × V / t] × [(Pa + Pw) / Ps]

Where:
- Q = Flow rate (ft³/h or m³/h)
- V = Volume of test dial (ft³ or m³)
- t = Time per revolution (seconds)
- Pa = Local atmospheric pressure (psia or kPa)
- Pw = Working pressure in meter (psig or kPa gauge)
- Ps = Standard pressure (14.73 psia or 101.325 kPa)

Flow Rates with Temperature Compensation:

Most meters have temperature-compensating devices correcting to standardized temperature (60°F or 15.4°C).

When meter is NOT temperature corrected and pressure exceeds 0.5 psig:

Formula: Q = [3600 × V / t] × [(Pa + Pw) / Ps] × [Ts / T]

Where:
- Ts = Base temperature (60°F or 15°C in absolute units)
- T = Gas temperature at meter in absolute units

Note: Gas heat values are based on temperature of 15°C.

Electronic Correctors:

Two common types:

1. TCI (Temperature Compensating Index):
   - Converts volume from operating conditions to reference temperature conditions
   - Temperature sensor in meter temperature well
   - Displays UNC (uncorrected) and COR (corrected) volumes
   - Correction factor typically close to 1.0 unless extreme temperatures

2. EVC (Electronic Volume Corrector):
   - Converts volume from operating to reference pressure AND temperature conditions
   - Temperature sensor in temperature well
   - Pressure transducer mounted in meter or separate connection
   - Displays pressure correction factor, temperature correction factor
   - May display live corrected flow rate

Electronic metering features:
- Continuous temperature/pressure readouts
- Correction factor displays
- Gas flow conditions indication
- Load survey data storage
- Computer connection capability (with software)

Using TCI/EVC for Clocking:

Live flow rate display may show corrected or uncorrected flow depending on parameter settings. Contact utility or manufacturer to verify.

If displaying corrected flow rate in ft³/h: Simply multiply by appropriate CV of gas for that area (no clocking or calculations needed).

Be aware: Utility can set display to ft³/h or m³/h.

Meter Types for Different Applications:

Diaphragm meter: Most common residential type, accurate at low flow rates, can be used for leak testing

Rotary meter: Used for higher flow commercial/industrial applications, NOT sufficiently accurate for leak testing small volumes

Electronic volume corrector: Corrects for both temperature and pressure

Electronic temperature compensating index: Corrects for temperature only

Using Meter to Leak Test:

Diaphragm or bellows meters can leak test at working pressure. Rotary and orifice meters are NOT considered sufficiently accurate.

Procedure:
1. Turn off all gas-consuming devices (appliances and pilots) as close to appliance as possible
2. Mark position of BOTH test dials using non-permanent marker
3. Wait at least 10 minutes
4. Check if either dial moved from marked position

Why mark both dials: Since they move at different speeds, unlikely both return to original position if leak exists. This catches the case where one dial completes a full revolution during test period.

Movement indicates: Gas has passed through meter and is leaking from pipe (assuming all devices are shut off).

Temperature and Pressure Effects:

If temperature of gas trapped in container increases: Pressure increases

If temperature of gas decreases in flexible container (diaphragm meter): Volume decreases

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following is the most common type of meter used on residential installations?
Which of the following meters corrects for temperature and pressure?
Why would a gas fitter clock a meter?
options: a) Only to check for a gas leak
b) To see how long it takes a test dial to complete one revolution
c) To determine how much gas an appliance consumes per hour
d) To check, for billing purposes, how much gas is consumed in one month
assignment_questions.correct_answer: c) To determine how much gas an appliance consumes per hour

assignment_questions.question: A pressure correction factor is needed when clocking an appliance when the _______.
options: a) Appliance input is over 400 MBtu/h
b) Meter pressure is greater than 0.5 psig
c) Meter pressure is greater than 2 psig
d) Meter pressure is greater than 5 psig
assignment_questions.correct_answer: b) Meter pressure is greater than 0.5 psig

assignment_questions.question: A natural gas meter with 7 in w.c. pressure is used to clock an appliance and it takes 24 sec for one revolution of a 2 ft³ test dial. What is the input of the appliance being fired?

A natural gas meter at sea level with 5 psig pressure is used to clock an appliance, it takes 60 sec for one revolution of a 5 ft³ test dial, and the CV of the gas is 1050 Btu/ft³. What is the input of the appliance being fired?

An appliance is installed at high elevation where atmospheric pressure is 85 kPa. A natural gas meter with 14 kPa pressure is used to clock the appliance, it takes 30 sec for one revolution of a 0.05 m³ test dial, and CV is 10.35 kW/m³. What is the input?
Rotary meters are very effective for leak testing a gas system.
To check if a test dial has possibly moved back to its original position when conducting a working pressure leak test using a diaphragm meter, you should _______.
options: c) Mark the position of the smallest test dial
d) Mark two positions on the smallest test dial

assignment_questions.question: If the temperature of a gas trapped in a container is increased, what happens to the pressure?
options: d) It depends on the type of gas

assignment_questions.question: If the temperature of a gas decreases in a flexible container (such as the bellows of a diaphragm meter), what happens to its volume?
options: d) It depends on the type of gas

assignment_questions.question: Figure shows TCI displaying temperature correct flow rate of 36.9 m³/h natural gas. If meter set pressure is 5 PSI, what is appliance input in Btu/h?
Gas heat values are based on a temperature of _______.

chapters.content:
Propane fuel containers store liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and must be properly sized to provide adequate vapor or liquid supply to connected appliances under various operating conditions.

Cylinder Reinspection:

A 100 lb propane cylinder must be reinspected and remarked every 10 years from the date of manufacture.

Vaporization Rate:

Vaporization rate is affected by:
- Liquid level in container (1/4 full = lowest rate for sizing)
- Temperature (lower temp = lower rate)
- Humidity (higher humidity = higher rate)
- Surface area (wetted surface transfers heat)
- Container size and type

The level of liquid propane in a cylinder HAS a significant effect on vaporization rate. Containers are sized based on 25% full (1/4 full) to ensure adequate supply even when nearly empty.

Container Capacity:

The largest cylinder has 1000 lb water capacity. Maximum allowable liquid propane capacity is 420 lb (42% by weight, 80% by volume).

Maximum fill level: 80% of water capacity by volume

Load Factors:

Average load factors for appliance types:
- Domestic: 0.5 (appliances cycle on/off)
- Commercial: 0.5
- Industrial: 0.75
- Agricultural: 1.0 (typically continuous operation)

Specific appliance load factors vary (see tables in textbook).

Effective Load Calculation:

Formula: Input rating × Load factor = Effective load

For multiple appliances:
1. Determine input rating for each appliance
2. Multiply each by proper load factor
3. Add all effective loads together = Total effective load

This accounts for the fact that thermostat-controlled appliances don't operate continuously.

Weather Conditions:

Always size containers for most trying weather conditions:
1. Determine normal operating periods
2. Determine lowest outside temperature during operation
3. Use appropriate humidity level for area

Sizing Tables:

Three tables for sizing containers:

Table 4A-1: ASME aboveground tanks (three tables based on 50-60%, 60-70%, 70-80% humidity)
Table 4A-2: ASME underground tanks (50°F constant)
Table 4A-3: DOT/TC portable, exchange, and stationary cylinders

All ratings based on container 1/4 full and show vaporization rate in Btu/h.

ASME Aboveground Tanks:

Procedure:
1. Select humidity table (50-60%, 60-70%, or 70-80%)
2. Select temperature column for lowest operating temperature
3. Read down until finding Btu rating equal to or greater than effective load
4. Read across to tank capacity (Gallons W.C.)

ASME Underground Tanks:

Underground tanks maintain approximately 50°F year-round due to earth temperature.

Procedure:
1. Read down 50°F column to find rating equal to or greater than effective load
2. Read across to determine tank capacity

Important: Never undersize underground tank. If undersized, frost line develops and vaporization drops to zero, requiring tank replacement.

DOT/TC Cylinders:

Four vaporization rates per cylinder:
- Winter high humidity (70%)
- Winter low humidity (30%)
- Summer high humidity (70%)
- Summer low humidity (30%)

Procedure:
1. Select column for most severe weather conditions
2. Determine cylinder type (portable, replaceable, stationary)
3. Read down to find rating equal to or greater than effective load
4. Read across to cylinder capacity

Note: Exchange cylinder installations require one reserve cylinder for each supply cylinder (e.g., two supply = four total cylinders).

Propane Vaporizers:

Direct-fired vaporizers used when equipment demand exceeds natural vaporizing capacity and larger tank is not practical.

Operation: Uses flame to directly heat liquid propane, accelerating vaporization. Essentially a boiler that doesn't build pressure.

Container Sizing for Liquid Withdrawal:

Based on two considerations:
1. Liquid withdrawal rate each day
2. Minimizing gas delivery frequency

Conversion:
- Effective load Btu/h ÷ 91,500 = gal/h
- Effective load Btu/h ÷ 24,174 = L/h

Installation Clearances:

Check CSA B149.2 for complete requirements. Key distances:

From property line/building openings (varies by tank size):
- 125 USWG or less: 10 ft
- Over 125 to 2,000 USWG: 10 ft
- Over 2,000 to 5,000 USWG: 15 ft
- Over 5,000 to 10,000 USWG: 25 ft

From sources of ignition: 3 ft minimum (10 ft from fill connection)

From building openings below relief valve: 5 ft horizontal

DOT/TC cylinders:
- 3 ft from building openings below relief valve
- 10 ft from air intakes or ignition sources
- Maximum 4 cylinders against a wall

Relief Valve Settings:

Relief valve setting of propane cylinder: 375 psig (for cylinders)

Some references show 312 psig for ASME tanks.

Purpose: Prevent tank/cylinder from rupturing due to overpressure.

Excess Flow Valves:

Purpose: Prevent excessive discharge of vapor or liquid in event of downstream line rupture.

Operation: Automatically restricts flow when flow rate exceeds design threshold.

Filler Valve:

Used to fill large stationary cylinders. Also acts as check valve to prevent excess flow (backflow).

Relief Valve Service:

A shut-off valve CAN be installed upstream of a relief valve to facilitate removal for servicing without emptying tank contents. However, during normal operation, this valve must be locked or sealed open.

Emergency Procedures:

If leak occurs between first and second-stage regulators:
First action: Shut off the propane container service valve

If relief valve on refillable propane container opens:
First action: Shut off the propane container service valve

Alternative if valve cannot be accessed: Cool tank with cold water to decrease pressure (reduces vapor pressure)

Overfill Indicator:

White fog or mist emitting from liquid level gauge indicates the maximum permitted filling level has been reached (80% full). This is caused by liquid propane venting and immediately vaporizing.

Vapor Pressure and Temperature:

The pressure in a propane container is directly related to the temperature of the liquid propane. As liquid temperature increases, vapor pressure increases.

What happens when temperature increases: Vapor pressure increases

Surface Area Effect:

The entire wetted surface of the container transfers heat and affects vaporization rate (not including top or bottom of horizontal cylinders in direct sun).

Cylinder Size Effect:

Larger cylinders have higher vaporization rates. From the options provided (20 lb, 40 lb, 200 lb, 300 lb), assuming all 1/4 full, the 300 lb cylinder will have highest Btu/h vaporization rate.

Humidity Effect:

Cylinders have LOWER vaporization rate when at higher humidity (this is opposite of what might be expected - the humidity comparison shows low humidity actually provides higher rates in the tables).

assignment_questions.question: How long may a 100 lb propane cylinder be in use before it must be reinspected and marked?
The level of liquid propane in a cylinder has no effect on its vaporization rate.
Assuming all propane cylinders are 1/4 full, which will have a higher Btu/h vaporization rate?
The largest cylinder made has a capacity of 1000 lb of water. What is the maximum allowable liquid propane capacity?
Which formula should be used when calculating the effective load that an appliance will place on a propane container?
options: a) Effective load = Btu/h of input
b) Effective load = input × load factor
c) Effective load = weight of propane × load factor
d) Effective load = gallons of liquid propane × 91 500
assignment_questions.correct_answer: b) Effective load = input × load factor

assignment_questions.question: Cylinders have a lower vaporization rate when they are at a higher humidity.
When the demand of an appliance is too high for an average-sized container, which would be a practical solution?
options: a) Install an excess flow valve
d) Install an autochange over a manifold

assignment_questions.question: Which unit of measurement is used to rate the fuel consumption of propane-fired stationary engines?
What happens to the vapor pressure in a cylinder when the temperature of liquid propane is increased?
options: d) It will decrease only if the liquid content is 80%

assignment_questions.question: Which surface(s) on a propane storage container transfer heat and affect the vaporization rate?
options: a) The entire wetted surface of the container
b) The entire surface, including top and bottom
c) The entire surface, excluding top or bottom
d) Only the surface that faces the sun and receives direct radiation
assignment_questions.correct_answer: a) The entire wetted surface of the container

assignment_questions.question: The pressure in a propane container is directly related to the _______.
options: a) Temperature of the liquid propane
b) Temperature of the propane gas
c) Volume of propane left in the cylinder
d) Size of the propane container
assignment_questions.correct_answer: a) Temperature of the liquid propane

assignment_questions.question: White fog or mist emitting from a liquid level gauge indicates that _______.
options: b) The cylinder or tank is damaged
c) The liquid level gauge is defective
d) The maximum permitted filling level has been reached
assignment_questions.correct_answer: d) The maximum permitted filling level has been reached

assignment_questions.question: The relief valve setting of a propane cylinder is _______.
What is the purpose of an excess flow valve?
options: a) To prevent liquid withdrawal from a tank
b) To prevent the tank from being filled too quickly
c) To prevent the tank from being overpressurized
d) To prevent the excessive discharge of vapor or liquid
assignment_questions.correct_answer: d) To prevent the excessive discharge of vapor or liquid

assignment_questions.question: A filler valve on a cylinder is used to _______.
options: a) Fill a large stationary cylinder
b) Provide a large capacity relief opening
c) Act as a check valve to prevent excess flow
d) Prevent the cylinder or tank from rupturing
assignment_questions.correct_answer: a) Fill a large stationary cylinder

assignment_questions.question: A shut-off valve cannot be installed upstream of a relief valve to facilitate removal for servicing without emptying the tank.
If a leak occurs in the propane line between the first and second-stage regulators, the first action must be to _______.
options: a) Close the excess flow valve
b) Open the fixed liquid level gauge
c) Shut off the propane container service valve
d) Decrease the pressure setting of the first-stage regulator
assignment_questions.correct_answer: c) Shut off the propane container service valve

assignment_questions.question: If the relief valve on a refillable propane container opens, the first action must be to _______.
options: a) Close the excess flow valve
b) Open the fixed liquid level gauge
c) Shut off the propane container service valve
d) Cool the tank with cold water to decrease the pressure
assignment_questions.correct_answer: c) Shut off the propane container service valve

documents.content:
CSA Unit 11 - Pressure Regulators Test (120 Questions)
Questions 1-40: Basic Concepts and Operation
What is the primary purpose of pressure regulators in a gas piping system? A) To increase gas flow rate B) To reduce and maintain downstream pressure and flow rate C) To filter impurities from gas D) To measure gas consumption
What happens if a gas appliance receives too much fuel because the gas pressure is too great? A) It will underfire B) It will overfire C) It will shut off automatically D) Nothing changes
What is the consequence if an appliance is overfired or underfired? A) It produces the correct amount of heat B) It operates more efficiently C) It may produce carbon monoxide and not work properly D) It extends the appliance lifespan
What are first-stage regulators primarily used for? A) Natural gas systems only B) Reducing propane container pressure to service line pressure C) Indoor applications only D) Emergency shut-off
What is another common name for service regulators in propane systems? A) First-stage regulators B) Second-stage regulators C) Line pressure regulators D) Emergency regulators
What do line pressure regulators reduce? A) Service line pressure to container pressure B) Building line pressure in branch lines C) Container pressure to atmospheric pressure D) Atmospheric pressure to building pressure
What does "downstream" refer to in gas flow terminology? A) Gas flow before it passes through the regulator B) Gas flow after it has passed through the regulator C) Gas flow in the opposite direction D) Gas flow at atmospheric pressure
What does "upstream" refer to in gas flow terminology? A) Gas flow after it passes through the regulator B) Gas flow before it passes through the regulator C) Gas flow upward through the system D) Gas flow at high pressure only
What type of regulators are most service, system, and appliance regulators? A) Pilot-operated B) Direct-operated C) Electronic-operated D) Manual-operated
How many essential elements does a direct-operated regulator have? A) Three B) Four C) Five D) Six
What is typically used as the loading element in a regulator? A) Diaphragm B) Spring C) Orifice D) Vent
What is typically used as the measuring element in a regulator? A) Spring B) Diaphragm C) Orifice D) Valve seat
What makes up the restricting element in a regulator? A) Spring and diaphragm B) Orifice and valve seat C) Vent and spring D) Diaphragm and vent
When an appliance shuts off, what happens to the pressure under the diaphragm? A) It decreases B) It remains constant C) It increases D) It fluctuates rapidly
When an appliance starts, what happens to cause the diaphragm to move downward? A) Upstream pressure increases B) Spring force overcomes downstream pressure C) Temperature increases D) Atmospheric pressure changes
What determines the position of the valve in relation to the orifice? A) Temperature changes B) Atmospheric pressure C) Balancing of forces acting on the measuring element D) Gas composition
What is the closing force in a regulator? A) Spring pressure B) Atmospheric pressure C) Upstream gas pressure D) Downstream gas pressure
What can be adjusted by changing the spring load? A) Gas temperature B) Amount of flow through the regulator C) Gas composition D) Atmospheric pressure
What is the desired outlet pressure known as? A) Lockup B) Setpoint C) Droop D) Offset
What is lockup pressure? A) Pressure below setpoint B) Pressure above setpoint used to shut the regulator off tight C) Atmospheric pressure D) Maximum inlet pressure
What describes the downstream pressure drop below setpoint? A) Lockup B) Setpoint C) Droop and offset D) Spring rate
For regulators with inlet pressure over 0.5 psi, what must they provide? A) Temperature compensation B) Positive shut-off when there is no gas demand C) Electronic control D) Manual override
What percentage of original outlet pressure setting do regulators usually lock up to? A) 5% B) 10% C) 15% D) 20%
What is the diaphragm typically made of? A) Steel B) Aluminum C) Neoprene D) Brass
What supports the diaphragm to allow downstream pressure to act evenly? A) Spring B) Metal plate C) Orifice D) Valve seat
Is it normal to detect a slight odor of gas at the vent opening? A) No, this always indicates damage B) Yes, because the diaphragm is slightly permeable C) Only in winter D) Only with propane
What can cause diaphragms to crack or tear? A) Normal operation only B) Age or exposure to chemicals C) High pressure only D) Low temperature only
What happens if dirt lodges between the orifice and valve seat? A) The regulator operates more efficiently B) The regulator cannot shut off C) Gas flow increases D) Nothing changes
What may happen if upstream pressure leaks downstream when appliances are shut off? A) Improved efficiency B) Damage to downstream components or gas buildup C) Automatic system shutdown D) Reduced gas consumption
What is the atmospheric vent also called? A) Safety vent B) Pressure vent C) Regulator vent D) Emergency vent
What would happen if the atmospheric vent was completely blocked? A) The regulator would work normally B) Downstream pressure would rise above setpoint C) Gas flow would stop completely D) The spring would break
What causes "hunting or cycling" in regulator operation? A) Complete vent blockage B) Partial vent blockage or restriction C) High spring tension D) Low inlet pressure
What drill size is typically used for small appliance regulator vents? A) #60 B) #78 C) #80 D) #90
Where do older appliances sometimes have their regulator vents? A) Outdoors only B) In the appliance combustion chamber C) In the basement D) In the attic
What four factors mainly affect droop in regulators? A) Temperature, humidity, altitude, gas type B) Spring rate, diaphragm area, orifice size, inlet pressure C) Pressure, volume, temperature, flow D) Material, age, installation, maintenance
How are control springs for regulators rated? A) By maximum pressure B) By temperature rating C) By force required to compress one inch D) By material composition
What type of spring provides the least droop and most accurate pressure control? A) Heaviest spring rate B) Medium spring rate C) Lightest available spring rate D) Variable spring rate
Why do larger diaphragms provide better accuracy? A) They are more durable B) They produce more force change for given pressure change C) They cost less D) They are easier to install
At what point does orifice size dictate maximum flow capacity? A) When valve is partially open B) When restricting element is wide open C) When valve is closed D) During startup only
What distance must the disc clear the orifice to be considered wide open? A) 1/8 of orifice diameter B) 1/4 of orifice diameter C) 1/2 of orifice diameter D) Equal to orifice diameter
Questions 41-80: Types, Safety Features, and Installation
What must be considered when changing orifice size? A) Temperature only B) Pressure only C) Not to oversize it to avoid unstable operation D) Gas composition only
What determines maximum flow capacity along with orifice size? A) Spring rate B) Diaphragm area C) Pressure difference on either side of orifice D) Temperature difference
When should maximum capacity be determined for regulator selection? A) At maximum inlet pressure B) At minimum inlet pressure C) At average inlet pressure D) At standard pressure
What prohibits a gas technician from working on service regulators? A) Local building codes B) CSA B149.1 unless authorized by distributor C) Insurance regulations D) Municipal bylaws
What should be done before beginning adjustments on non-utility regulators? A) Shut off all gas B) Consult manufacturer's instructions C) Call the gas company D) Test all appliances
What tools should be used for regulator pressure adjustments? A) Any available tools B) Proper tools with correct range and accuracy C) Only electronic tools D) Only mechanical tools
If regulator pressure is too high, which direction should the adjusting screw be turned? A) Clockwise B) Counter-clockwise C) Either direction D) 180 degrees
If regulator pressure is too low, which direction should the adjusting screw be turned? A) Counter-clockwise B) Clockwise C) Either direction D) 90 degrees
What should be done after adjusting regulator pressure? A) Turn off gas immediately B) Check operation of downstream appliances C) Wait 24 hours D) Call for inspection
What drill size is typically used for vent limiting orifices? A) #60 B) #70 C) #78 D) #85
If a diaphragm ruptures, what is the maximum leakage allowed for most regulators? A) 0.5 ft³/h B) 1 ft³/h C) 2 ft³/h D) 5 ft³/h
At what gas pressure is the 1 ft³/h leakage rate measured? A) 3.5 inches w.c. B) 7 inches w.c. C) 10 inches w.c. D) 14 inches w.c.
What happens to regulator capacity when a vent limiting orifice accessory is installed? A) Capacity increases B) Capacity stays the same C) Capacity must be reduced D) Capacity doubles
What is the maximum flow rate allowed for natural gas leak limiting devices? A) 1 ft³/h B) 2.5 ft³/h C) 5 ft³/h D) 10 ft³/h
What is the maximum flow rate allowed for propane leak limiting devices? A) 0.5 ft³/h B) 1 ft³/h C) 2.5 ft³/h D) 5 ft³/h
Where must regulators equipped with leak limiters be installed? A) Outdoors only B) In ventilated spaces C) Underground only D) In sealed enclosures
Why should vent limiting devices not be used outdoors? A) They work too well B) They may become clogged by moisture or insects C) They are not weather resistant D) They freeze in cold weather
For ball check vent limiters, how should the regulator be mounted? A) Vertically only B) Horizontally with vent limiter vertical up C) At any angle D) Upside down
What design feature decreases regulator droop? A) Larger spring B) Smaller diaphragm C) Pitot tube D) Thicker orifice
Where does the pitot tube connect the underside of the diaphragm? A) Upstream pressure point B) Atmospheric vent C) Vena contracta area D) Spring chamber
What is the phenomenon opposite of droop called? A) Lift B) Boost C) Rise

CSA Unit 11  
Chapter 1                                  
Pressure Regulators
Pressure regulators are installed in a gas piping system to reduce and 
maintain the downstream pressure and flow rate that allow downstream 
appliances to operate safely and efficiently. A thorough understanding of 
the principal elements of pressure regulators and their operation is 
necessary in order to properly install and service gas equipment.
MK by Mike Kapin
Created
Copywrite 2025
Objectives
1
Describe the need for 
pressure regulators
2
Describe the basic 
operation of a regulator
3
Locate the codes and 
regulations pertaining to 
regulators
4
Distinguish between the 
different types of 
regulators
5
Describe the selection 
requirements
6
Describe the location and 
piping practices
7
Troubleshoot common regulator problems
Terminology
Term
Abbreviation (Symbol)
Definition
An air/gas proportioning regulator 
(ratio regulator)
Is similar to a zero requlator, 
except that air pressure is applied 
to the vent opening on the spring 
side of the diaphragm through a 
sensing line connected to an air 
supply line delivering combustion 
air to the nozzle mix burner
Droop and offset
The downstream pressure drop 
below setpoint
Lockup
The pressure above setpoint that is 
used to shut the regulator off tight
Servo
A mechanism set in operation by 
other mechanisms
Setpoint
The desired outlet pressure
Zero governor (requlator)
Designed to deliver an outlet 
pressure equivalent to 
atmospheric pressure
The Need for Pressure 
Regulators
Gas pressures in supply mains (natural gas) and from storage containers 
(propane) are higher than the maximum allowed inlet pressure of 
connected appliances. For this reason, gas pressures must be controlled 
to fall within an appropriate pressure range, depending on the operating 
characteristics of installed appliances.
Purpose of Gas Pressure 
Regulators
Reduce and maintain safe operating pressure
For the building and/or connected appliances regardless of 
changes in the gas flow or upstream pressure.
Provide means for pressure adjustment
By which the pressure to connected appliances or burners can be 
adjusted, set, and maintained.
Consequences of Incorrect Gas 
Pressure
If
Then
The inlet pressure to the regulator is over 0.5 
psi (3.5 kPa)
The requlator must provide an additional 
function to act as a positive shut-off device 
to ensure that downstream pressure does 
not build up to unsafe levels under no flow 
conditions.
A gas appliance receives too much fuel 
because the gas pressure is too great
It will overfire.
If the gas appliance receives too little fue
It will underfire.
If an appliance is overfired or underfired
•
It will produce too much (overfired) and 
too little (underfired) heat.
•
Combustion characteristics could 
change, resulting in carbon monoxide 
generation.
•
The appliance may not work properly or 
efficiently.
Main Categories of Gas Pressure Regulators
Category
Description
First-stage regulators
•
Used in all permanently installed propane systems to reduce the propane container pressure to service line pressure delivered 
to the second stage requlator
See Figure 1-1
Service regulators (commonly called second-stage regulators in propane systems)
•
Used in both natural gas and propane systems to reduce the service line pressure to building line pressure at the gas meter set
See Figure 1-2
•
Commonly called second-stage regulators in line propane systems
See Figure 1-1
Line pressure regulators
•
Used to reduce the building line pressure in a branch line where the pressure required by appliances or equipment on that 
branch line is less than the pressure in the main building line
See Figure 1-2
•
Referred as "system regulators" in CSA B149.1, prior to 2005
Natural Gas Installation: 
Service and Line Pressure 
Regulators
Figure 1-2 Natural gas installation showing location of service regulator 
and line pressure regulators
Direction of Flow in Pressure 
Regulators
When installing a pressure regulator, the direction of gas flow is critical 
for proper operation of the regulator. An arrow on the regulator casing 
indicates the direction of flow. Be certain that you install the regulator so 
the flow arrow points in the direction of flow. (Direction of flow will be 
covered in more detail later in this chapter.)
Understanding Gas Flow 
Terminology
Knowing these two commonly used terms is important since they are used 
often to explain where to place appliances. These refer to the placing of an 
item in the system according to the flow of the gas:
•
downstream; and
•
upstream.
Flow
Description
Gas downstream of the regulator
Refers to the gas flow after it has 
passed through the requlator
Gas upstream of the regulator
Refers to the gas flow before it 
passes through the regulator
Pilot-Operated vs. Direct-
Operated Regulators
Most pressure regulators are either pilot-operated or direct-operated. 
Pilot-operated regulators consist of two requlators with the same 
essential components as direct-operated units. The pilot can simply and 
effectively be considered a second requlator, providing additional control 
to the main regulator, improving overall sensitivity and, ultimately, 
accuracy. Pilot-operated regulators are used for high-capacity 
applications to supply gas to commercial, institutional, and industrial 
buildings.
This level of training focuses on the operation of direct operated 
regulators, although, it covers servo regulation, which by definition is a 
type of pilot operated control, as it applies to the appliance regulators 
built into combination gas valves.
Basic Operation of a Regulator
Most service, system, and appliance regulators are direct-operated regulators that work in basically the same way.
A direct-operated regulator is defined as any self-contained valve and actuator combination that automatically adjusts the 
flow in direct response to changes in downstream pressure, thereby matching the gas demand. Figure 1-3 illustrates a direct-
operated regulator.
Essential Elements of a 
Direct-Operated Regulator
As shown in Figure 1-3, these regulators have four essential elements.
Element
Description
Loading element
Usually a spring
Measuring element
Usually a diaphragm
Restricting element
An orifice and valve seat
Atmospheric vent
A vent on the atmospheric side 
of the diaphragm
How a Regulator Works: 
Appliance Shut-off
Here is how a regulator works:
1. When the appliance shuts off, the pressure increases under the 
diaphragm (or measuring element), pushing it up with greater force than 
the spring (or loading element) is exerting downward. As a result, the 
valve closes against the orifice (in a configuration known as the 
restricting element). Air exiting the vent allows the diaphragm to move 
freely.
How a Regulator Works: 
Appliance Start-up
2. When the appliance starts, the loss in pressure downstream causes the 
spring to overcome the downstream pressure exerted on the measuring 
element. As a result, the diaphragm moves downward, thus opening the 
valve. Air entering the vent allows the diaphragm to move freely.
How a Regulator Works: 
Equilibrium
3. The balancing of forces acting on the measuring element determines 
the position of the valve in relation to the orifice. The diaphragm and 
valve stabilize when the force under the diaphragm equals the force 
exerted by the spring. At this point, the regulator has found its point of 
equilibrium and the flow rate and pressure downstream match that which 
is required by the system.
Regulator Response to Gas 
Demand Changes
If additional appliances start or an increase in firing rate occurs, the 
diaphragm moves downward and the valve stabilizes in a new position to 
the orifice, allowing more gas flow at the same pressure.
If gas demand decreases, the diaphragm moves upward and the valve 
stabilizes in a new position in relation to the orifice, allowing less gas flow 
at the same pressure. Air entering and exiting the vent allows the 
diaphragm to move freely.
Note: The closing force in a regulator is the downstream gas pressure.
The Loading Element: 
Spring
The loading element is used to counterbalance the downstream 
pressure. It is usually a spring.
The amount of spring pressure on the diaphragm determines the 
position of the restricting element.
Changing the spring load can adjust the amount of flow through the 
regulator.
Flow and Pressure Regulation Terminology
Flow and pressure regulation
Description
Setpoint
•
The desired outlet pressure is known as the setpoint.
•
A perfect regulator could maintain downstream pressure equal to setpoint under all flow rates, but in reality, as flow rate 
increases, the downstream pressure decreases.
Lockup
•
Lockup is the pressure above setpoint that is used to shut the requlator off tight. In many requlators, the orifice has a machined 
edge, while the disk is made of a soft material. To make a tight seal, the requlator must increase the downstream pressure to 
force the disk onto the machined edge. This extra amount of pressure required is called the lockup pressure.
•
Regulators that have an inlet pressure over 0.5 psi (3.5 kPa) must provide a positive shut-off when there is no gas demand 
downstream. These regulators usually lock up to within 10% of the original outlet pressure setting.
Droop and offset
•
Droop and offset describe the downstream pressure drop below setpoint. At this point, the valve is fully open, and there is an 
increased gas demand downstream. Droop can be expressed as a percentage of setpoint pressure. Manufacturers publish 
regulator capacities according to their amounts of droop. These are generally for 10% droop and 20% droop. The accuracy of a 
regulator is determined by the amount of flow it can pass for a given amount of droop. The closer the requlator is to setpoint, 
the more accurate it is.
•
If the performance of a typical regulator is plotted on a graph, the graph will show how the flow rate of gas drops off drastically 
as the gas flo

CSA Unit
Chapter 1                                  Pressure Regulators
Pressure regulators are installed in a gas piping system to reduce and maintain the downstream pressure and flow rate that allow downstream appliances to operate safely and efficiently. A thorough understanding of the principal elements of pressure regulators and their operation is necessary in order to properly install and service gas equipment.
MK
by Mike Kapin
Objectives
1
Describe the need for pressure regulators
2
Describe the basic operation of a regulator
3
Locate the codes and regulations pertaining to regulators
4
Distinguish between the different types of regulators
5
Describe the selection requirements
6
Describe the location and piping practices
7
Troubleshoot common regulator problems
Terminology
Term
Abbreviation (Symbol)
Definition
An air/gas proportioning regulator (ratio regulator)
Is similar to a zero requlator, except that air pressure is applied to the vent opening on the spring side of the diaphragm through a sensing line connected to an air supply line delivering combustion air to the nozzle mix burner
Droop and offset
The downstream pressure drop below setpoint
Lockup
The pressure above setpoint that is used to shut the regulator off tight
Servo
A mechanism set in operation by other mechanisms
Setpoint
The desired outlet pressure
Zero governor (requlator)
Designed to deliver an outlet pressure equivalent to atmospheric pressure
The Need for Pressure Regulators
Gas pressures in supply mains (natural gas) and from storage containers (propane) are higher than the maximum allowed inlet pressure of connected appliances. For this reason, gas pressures must be controlled to fall within an appropriate pressure range, depending on the operating characteristics of installed appliances.
Purpose of Gas Pressure Regulators
Reduce and maintain safe operating pressure
For the building and/or connected appliances regardless of changes in the gas flow or upstream pressure.
Provide means for pressure adjustment
By which the pressure to connected appliances or burners can be adjusted, set, and maintained.
Consequences of Incorrect Gas Pressure
If
Then
The inlet pressure to the regulator is over 0.5 psi (3.5 kPa)
The requlator must provide an additional function to act as a positive shut-off device to ensure that downstream pressure does not build up to unsafe levels under no flow conditions.
A gas appliance receives too much fuel because the gas pressure is too great
It will overfire.
If the gas appliance receives too little fue
It will underfire.
If an appliance is overfired or underfired
It will produce too much (overfired) and too little (underfired) heat.
Combustion characteristics could change, resulting in carbon monoxide generation.
The appliance may not work properly or efficiently.
Main Categories of Gas Pressure Regulators
Category
Description
First-stage regulators
Used in all permanently installed propane systems to reduce the propane container pressure to service line pressure delivered to the second stage requlator
See Figure 1-1
Service regulators (commonly called second-stage regulators in propane systems)
Used in both natural gas and propane systems to reduce the service line pressure to building line pressure at the gas meter set
See Figure 1-2
Commonly called second-stage regulators in line propane systems
See Figure 1-1
Line pressure regulators
Used to reduce the building line pressure in a branch line where the pressure required by appliances or equipment on that branch line is less than the pressure in the main building line
See Figure 1-2
Referred as "system regulators" in CSA B149.1, prior to 2005
Appliance regulators
Used to reduce low (max 0.5 psi) building or branch line pressure to the pressure required by the appliance
Often built into a combination control
Also see the definitions provided in CSA B149.1.
Natural Gas Installation: Service and Line Pressure Regulators
Figure 1-2 Natural gas installation showing location of service regulator and line pressure regulators
Direction of Flow in Pressure Regulators
When installing a pressure regulator, the direction of gas flow is critical for proper operation of the regulator. An arrow on the regulator casing indicates the direction of flow. Be certain that you install the regulator so the flow arrow points in the direction of flow. (Direction of flow will be covered in more detail later in this chapter.)
Understanding Gas Flow Terminology
Knowing these two commonly used terms is important since they are used often to explain where to place appliances. These refer to the placing of an item in the system according to the flow of the gas:
downstream; and
upstream.
Flow
Description
Gas downstream of the regulator
Refers to the gas flow after it has passed through the requlator
Gas upstream of the regulator
Refers to the gas flow before it passes through the regulator
Pilot-Operated vs. Direct-Operated Regulators
Most pressure regulators are either pilot-operated or direct-operated. Pilot-operated regulators consist of two requlators with the same essential components as direct-operated units. The pilot can simply and effectively be considered a second requlator, providing additional control to the main regulator, improving overall sensitivity and, ultimately, accuracy. Pilot-operated regulators are used for high-capacity applications to supply gas to commercial, institutional, and industrial buildings.
This level of training focuses on the operation of direct operated regulators, although, it covers servo regulation, which by definition is a type of pilot operated control, as it applies to the appliance regulators built into combination gas valves.
Basic Operation of a Regulator
Most service, system, and appliance regulators are direct-operated regulators that work in basically the same way.
A direct-operated regulator is defined as any self-contained valve and actuator combination that automatically adjusts the flow in direct response to changes in downstream pressure, thereby matching the gas demand. Figure 1-3 illustrates a direct-operated regulator.
Essential Elements of a Direct-Operated Regulator
As shown in Figure 1-3, these regulators have four essential elements.
Element
Description
Loading element
Usually a spring
Measuring element
Usually a diaphragm
Restricting element
An orifice and valve seat
Atmospheric vent
A vent on the atmospheric side of the diaphragm
How a Regulator Works: Appliance Shut-off
Here is how a regulator works:
1. When the appliance shuts off, the pressure increases under the diaphragm (or measuring element), pushing it up with greater force than the spring (or loading element) is exerting downward. As a result, the valve closes against the orifice (in a configuration known as the restricting element). Air exiting the vent allows the diaphragm to move freely.
How a Regulator Works: Appliance Start-up
2. When the appliance starts, the loss in pressure downstream causes the spring to overcome the downstream pressure exerted on the measuring element. As a result, the diaphragm moves downward, thus opening the valve. Air entering the vent allows the diaphragm to move freely.
How a Regulator Works: Equilibrium
3. The balancing of forces acting on the measuring element determines the position of the valve in relation to the orifice. The diaphragm and valve stabilize when the force under the diaphragm equals the force exerted by the spring. At this point, the regulator has found its point of equilibrium and the flow rate and pressure downstream match that which is required by the system.
Regulator Response to Gas Demand Changes
If additional appliances start or an increase in firing rate occurs, the diaphragm moves downward and the valve stabilizes in a new position to the orifice, allowing more gas flow at the same pressure.
If gas demand decreases, the diaphragm moves upward and the valve stabilizes in a new position in relation to the orifice, allowing less gas flow at the same pressure. Air entering and exiting the vent allows the diaphragm to move freely.
Note: The closing force in a regulator is the downstream gas pressure.
The Loading Element: Spring
The loading element is used to counterbalance the downstream pressure. It is usually a spring.
The amount of spring pressure on the diaphragm determines the position of the restricting element.
Changing the spring load can adjust the amount of flow through the regulator.
Flow and Pressure Regulation Terminology
Flow and pressure regulation
Description
Setpoint
The desired outlet pressure is known as the setpoint.
A perfect regulator could maintain downstream pressure equal to setpoint under all flow rates, but in reality, as flow rate increases, the downstream pressure decreases.
Lockup
Lockup is the pressure above setpoint that is used to shut the requlator off tight. In many requlators, the orifice has a machined edge, while the disk is made of a soft material. To make a tight seal, the requlator must increase the downstream pressure to force the disk onto the machined edge. This extra amount of pressure required is called the lockup pressure.
Regulators that have an inlet pressure over 0.5 psi (3.5 kPa) must provide a positive shut-off when there is no gas demand downstream. These regulators usually lock up to within 10% of the original outlet pressure setting.
Droop and offset
Droop and offset describe the downstream pressure drop below setpoint. At this point, the valve is fully open, and there is an increased gas demand downstream. Droop can be expressed as a percentage of setpoint pressure. Manufacturers publish regulator capacities according to their amounts of droop. These are generally for 10% droop and 20% droop. The accuracy of a regulator is determined by the amount of flow it can pass for a given amount of droop. The closer the requlator is to setpoint, the more accurate it is.
If the performance of a typical regulator is plotted on a graph, the graph will show how the flow

General Requirements for Pressure Regulators
In a residential application using propane, propane vapour pressure in either a piping or tubing system between the first- stage and second-stage regulator shall not be higher than 1 0 psig (70 kPa). In other applications using propane, means shall be provided to prevent 	of propane.
Every regulator shall be certified and be of sufficient size to provide the required flow of gas at the extremes of
pressures to which the regulator can be exposed.
A line pressure regulator shall have a 	installed upstream of the regulator; and either a line relief device or an overpressure protection device.
In regards to the general requirements for pressure regulators, a pressure regulator shall not be
The regulator vent and relief device vent shall terminate
When a line pressure regulator is required and the inlet supply pressure to the regulator exceeds 0.5 psig (3.5 kPa), it shall be of the 	type.
Clause 7.5.2 states that the moisture exhaust duct shall not terminate within 	ft in any direction of a service regulator.
Additional Requirements for Natural Gas Applications
When used on a system operating at 2 psi (1 4 kPa) or less, a line pressure regulator equipped with a leak limiting system orificed for 	shall be exempt from the requirement of Clause 5.2.1 .5(b).
A regulator with vent limiting means shall be installed in a 	space only
Excluding specific Code exceptions, Propane shall not be piped into or within any building in the 	phase
Except as specified in Clauses 5.2.2.4 and 5.2.3, when a line pressure regulator is not equipped with an internal relief device, it shall have immediately downstream an 			device or a line relief device as required in Clause 5.2.1.5(b), with a discharge setting of either (a) not less than 	times and not more than 	times the delivery pressure on systems operating up to 	psi (35 kPa); or (b) not less than 	times and not more than
times the delivery pressure on systems operating at more than 5 psi (35 kPa).
Venting and Relief Devices
Except as specified in Clauses 5.5.2, 5.5.3, and 5.6.2 for natural gas and Clauses 5.5.3, 5.5.10, and 5.6.1 .3 for propane, when an automatic valve, diaphragm valve, combination control, pressure regulator without internal relief, or other control device (excluding a gas overpressure relief valve) that requires venting is installed, it shall be vented
to a safe location outdoors by a vent line
The relieving pressure setting of the line relief device shall be not 	than that of the lowest-rated component or accessory located downstream.
Discharge lines from two or more hydrostatic relief devices may run into a common discharge header, provided that the cross-sectional area of the header is at least 	to the sum of the 	areas of the individual discharge lines and that the header is not connected to any vent or bleed line.
For natural gas applications, when a diaphragm valve or combination control is installed on an appliance with an inlet supply pressure not in excess of 	psig (		kPa) and using a gas lighter than air, it may be vented into the appliance 	adjacent to the continuous pilot provided that the terminus of the bleed vent is in a burner tip having a melting point in excess of 		that is securely held in a fixed position relative to the pilot flame and that will not adversely affect the operation of the thermal element.
Multiple Valve and Control Device Venting
When two or more, or any combination of, automatic valves, diaphragm valves, combination controls, other control devices (excluding gas overpressure relief valves), or pressure regulators without internal relief that require venting are installed, they may be connected into a single vent, provided that (a) there is compliance with i Clause 5.5.1 (a) and (b) for inlet pressure not in excess of	psig ii Clause 5.5.4(a) and (b) for inlet pressure in excess of 0.5 psig (3.5
kPa); and (b) the single vent line has an area of not less than 	the total area of the connected bleed vents.
A hydrostatic relief device (to relieve at a safe location outdoors) shall be installed between each pair of shut-off valves on propane liquid piping. The start-to-discharge pressure setting of such a hydrostatic relief device shall be neither less than 	psi (   kPa) nor more than 	psi (	kPa).
Except as specified in Clause 5.5.5, when a gas overpressure relief valve or a pressure regulator with internal relief is installed, it shall be vented separately to a safe location outdoors by a vent line (a) of steel pipe, copper, or 	 tubing that complies with Clause 6.2; and (b) of the following size: (i) the 		of the vent outlet of the valve or regulator increased as specified by the manufacturer's instructions; or (ii) in the absence of manufacturer's instructions, the nominal pipe size of the vent outlet of the valve or regulator increased by one pipe size diameter for every 50 ft (15 m) or part thereof that the vent line extends beyond the initial 	ft (	m). This increase shall be made at the connection on the
Gas Overpressure Relief Devices and Vent Terminations
When two or more gas overpressure relief devices are installed, they may be connected into a single vent line, provided that (a) there is compliance with Clause 5.5.4(a) and (b); (b) the single vent line has an area equal to the largest relief device opening or pressure regulator opening plus 	% of the total area of the other relief device openings; (c) the variance between the inlet pressures of the overpressure relief valves does not exceed 10%; and (d) the variance between the outlet pressures of the overpressure relief valves does not exceed 1 0%.
The outdoor vent termination of regulators and line relief devices shall be equipped with a means to prevent the entry of
, or foreign material.
A safety limit or a safety relief device shall not be 	, 	, or in any way made ineffective by a valve or other device.
The discharge from relief devices shall terminate outdoors with the clearances specified in
For propane applications, except as specified in Clause 5.6.1.3, a pressure regulator, line relief device, or hydrostatic relief device on an appliance using gas heavier than air shall be equipped with a 	(a) in accordance with Clause 5.5.4(a) and (b); and (b) terminating outdoors in accordance with Clause 5.5.9.
For propane applications, a regulator vent, line relief device, or hydrostatic relief device discharging vertically upward shall be provided with a 	. When discharging downward, it shall be provided with a 	.
Additional Requirements for Propane Applications
Regulator Installation and Venting
A regulator shall be firmly secured to the 	valve, or the regulator bracket on the wall or hood, or in some other appropriate manner. When installed outdoors and subject to inclement weather, the regulator shall be protected as necessary from exposure to weather conditions.
When used on a system operating at 2 psig (1 4 kPa) or less, a line pressure regulator equipped with a leak limiting system orificed for 	shall be exempt from the requirement of Clause 5.2.1 .5(b).
A regulator with vent limiting means shall be installed in a 	space only.
Not less than 	regulation shall be utilized on all permanent propane installations.
A regulator installed outdoors or in an unheated area shall be positioned so that the bonnet vent opening discharges vertically 	, except that a single-stage regulator of a capacity not exceeding 	Btuh may be installed in a horizontal position, provided that it is protected from inclement weather.
Appliance and Pilot Pressure Regulators
Propane Applications
An appliance that can be subjected, through supply pressure, design, creepage, or fluctuation, to propane pressure in excess of that for which it is rated shall be equipped with an appliance 	.
When an appliance pressure regulator is required by Clause 5.6.1 .1, the propane supply to the pilot or group of pilots shall be regulated by an approved pressure regulator independent of the 	propane supply.
When an appliance pressure regulator without internal relief having an inlet pressure not in excess of 	psig (	kPa) is installed on an appliance, it shall be vented to the outdoors unless it is constructed or equipped with a
device to limit the escape of gas from the vent opening in the event of diaphragm failure, and the opening in the device shall restrict the escape of gas to not more than 	per hour of a gas having a specific gravity of 	. A regulator with vent limiting means shall not be installed in a confined space.
Natural Gas Applications
When an appliance pressure regulator without internal relief having an inlet pressure not in excess of 2 psig (14 kPa) is installed on an appliance, it shall be vented to the outdoors unless it is constructed or equipped with a device to limit the escape of gas from the vent opening in the event of diaphragm failure, and the opening in the device shall restrict the escape of gas to not more than 	per hour of a gas having a specific gravity of 	. A regulator with vent limiting means shall be installed in a ventilated space only.

 yes, but only temporarily

Unit 11 – Chapter 01: Pressure regulators

a) Spring

b) Ruptured diaphragm

a) To keep the colour of the flame constant 
b) To maintain even outlet heated air temperatures 
c) To maintain a constant gas pressure at the gas valve inlet 
d) To increase and maintain higher pressures as the load increases

a) Decreased flow velocity

a) Increased flow velocity 
b) The inlet pressure to the regulator 
c) The pressure under the diaphragm 
d) The adjustable spring above the diaphragm

a) The orifice size is changed 
b) The adjusting screw is screwed out

a) Allow gas to escape

d) Opening force of the spring is equal to the closing force of the downstream 
pressure
